gw.api.heatmap

Class HeatMapGeneratorBase

  • java.lang.Object
    • gw.api.heatmap.HeatMapGeneratorBase

  • public abstract class HeatMapGeneratorBase
extends java.lang.Object
    Base class to generate a heat map display of map point data, such as (in ClaimCenter) claims associated with a catastrophe. (Note: extend HeatMapGenerator, a subclass of this class, to create a map.)

    Heatmaps show a map of part of the world with a color overlay that represents the map points. For example, the overlay may count the number of map points at each location; locations with one map point in blue and locations with ten or more map points in red, with intermediate colors for intermediate values. Or the overlay could represent a dollar amount associated with a geographic location; in this case each color would represent a dollar range.

    Heatmaps support zoom, pan, and selection of a rectangular area on the map.

    To use a heatmap, you must license a map service, such as Bing Maps, and provide a map template that generates appropriate HTML and Javascript for that service. The Bing Maps template is included in CC. Map templates for other map services may be available as Accelerators from Guidewire, which you must add to your configuration.

    Here are the main steps to configure a map. (For full details please see the documentation):

    • Subclass HeatMapGenerator. Provide a mapPointQuery() method to get map points from the database. If appropriate, override the getSelectionMessage(), getWeight() and mapCountToPixelColor() methods. If desired, provide values for SelectionMessageID, InitialHeight and InitialWidth, or other optional settings.
    • Subclass HeatMapDataSet to create a dataset. Set DataSets to include the dataset.
    • (optional) Subclass LatLong to include additional data for each point, such as a dollar amount.
    • (optional) Use HeatMapLegend.generateLegendIcon() to generate a map legend.
    • Create a screen that uses the map with the appropriate widgets and settings (see documentation)
    • Set the HeatMapServiceTemplate parameter in config.xml with the name of the map template. Set the HeatMapCredential parameter to the credential or password provided by map service provider
    Author:
    jfehrle

    • Field Detail

      • MAX_ZOOM

        public static final int MAX_ZOOM
        The maximum supported zoom level. The map service may have a lower limit.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Constructor Detail

      • HeatMapGeneratorBase

        public HeatMapGeneratorBase(java.lang.String mapName)
        Constructor
        Parameters:
        mapName - The name of the map, used as a handle to identify the state associated with a map and to distinguish between multiple maps. Multiple maps can be on a single screen or on different screens.

        The map name must be unique across all screens to create independent maps. If a map name is reused on two screens, then the map state (e.g. query, centerpoint, zoom level) will be shared across those screens.

    • Method Detail

      • setDataSets

        public final void setDataSets(HeatMapDataSet... dataSets)
        Sets the dataSets to use for the map. Note that each dataset becomes associated with this HeatMapGenerator instance, so HeatMapDataSet objects can't be shared between HeatMapGenerator instances.
        Parameters:
        dataSets - an array of datasets for the map

      • getHeatMapServiceTemplateName

        public java.lang.String getHeatMapServiceTemplateName()
        The class name of the heat map template, which is initialized to the class specified in the 'HeatMapServiceTemplate' configuration parameter in config.xml. It should contain the fully-qualified class name of the map template, for example "gw.api.heatmap.BingMap". Each map service will require its own template.
        Returns:
        The fully-qualified class name of the map template.

      • getHeatMapCredential

        public static java.lang.String getHeatMapCredential()
        The 'HeatMapCredential' configuration parameter from config.xml, which should be set the credential or password value required by the map service. The map template will pass this value to the browser.
        Returns:
        The credential.

      • isHeatMapConfigured

        public static boolean isHeatMapConfigured()
        Tells whether the heat map is configured in config.xml. Currently, that means the HeatMapServiceTemplate and HeatMapCredential are set to non-empty strings. This could be used to control whether to display a screen with a heat map.
        Returns:
        True if the map is configured.

      • getMapName

        public java.lang.String getMapName()
        The name of the map, used as a handle to identify the state associated with a map and to distinguish between multiple maps. Multiple maps can be on a single screen or on different screens.

        The map name must be unique across all screens to create independent maps. If a map name is reused on two screens, then the map state (e.g. query, centerpoint, zoom level) will be shared across those screens.

        The map name is a parameter in the HeatMapGenerator() constructor.

        Returns:
        The map name.

      • setMargin

        public void setMargin(int margin)
        Set the margin to apply on each edge of the map for computing the size of the bounding box. (See computeBoundingBox().)

        The margin is the minimum number of pixels between the edge and the center of the square representing a map point (e.g. a claim in ClaimCenter).

        Parameters:
        margin - The margin setting in pixels.

      • setMapFrameHTML

      • setSelection

        public void setSelection(LatLong point1,
                         LatLong point2)
        Sets a rectangular selection area on the map. The longitude selection always goes east from the first point. This allows for selections that span the date line. For example, the selection points (0, 0), (1, 1) indicate a 1 degree span of latitude and longitude. Reversing the points as (1, 1), (0,0) indicates 359 degrees of longitude and 1 degree of latitude.
        Parameters:
        point1 - The first corner of the rectangle.
        point2 - The diagonally opposite corner of the rectangle

      • getSelectionPoint1

        public LatLong getSelectionPoint1()
        The first corner of the selected rectangle. The longitude selection always goes east from the first point. This allows for selections that span the date line. For example, the selection points (0, 0), (1, 1) indicate a 1 degree span of latitude and longitude. Reversing the points as (1, 1), (0,0) indicates 359 degrees of longitude and 1 degree of latitude.
        Returns:
        The first corner.

      • getSelectionPoint2

        public LatLong getSelectionPoint2()
        The second corner of the selected rectangle. The longitude selection always goes east from the first point. This allows for selections that span the date line. For example, the selection points (0, 0), (1, 1) indicate a 1 degree span of latitude and longitude. Reversing the points as (1, 1), (0,0) indicates 359 degrees of longitude and 1 degree of latitude.
        Returns:
        The second corner.

        public void setAreaOfInterest(LatLong areaOfInterestPoint1,
                              LatLong areaOfInterestPoint2)

For example, the points (0, 0), (1, 1) indicate a 1 degree span of latitude and longitude. Reversing the points as (1, 1), (0,0) indicates 359 degrees of longitude and 1 degree of latitude.
        Parameters:
        areaOfInterestPoint1 - The first corner of the rectangle.
        areaOfInterestPoint2 - The diagonally opposite corner of the rectangle

      • getZoom

        public int getZoom()
        The zoom level of the map. 0 shows the largest area (the entire world). Increasing the zoom by 1 doubles the scale of the map up to the least of MAX_ZOOM or the limit imposed by the map service.

        This value changes as the user zooms and pans the map.

        Returns:
        The zoom level.

      • setZoom

        public void setZoom(int zoom)
        Set the zoom level of the map. 0 shows the largest area (the entire world). Increasing the zoom by 1 doubles the scale of the map up to the least of MAX_ZOOM or the limit imposed by the map service.

        This value changes as the user zooms and pans the map.

        Parameters:
        zoom - The zoom level

        Returns:
        The initial height of the map in pixels

      • setOverlayBackgroundColor

        public void setOverlayBackgroundColor(java.awt.Color color)
        Set the background color for the map overlay (which contains the markers for the points). A color with an alpha of 0 makes the overlay completely transparent where there are no point markers. A value at or near 255 will hide the underlying map layer completely. Intermediate alpha values with white or black will make the underlying map lighter or darker and may increase contrast for the point markers.
        Parameters:
        color - The background color for the map overlay.

      • getOverlayBackgroundColor

        public java.awt.Color getOverlayBackgroundColor()
        The background color for the map overlay (which contains the markers for the points). A color with an alpha of 0 makes the overlay completely transparent where there are no point markers. A value at or near 255 will hide the underlying map layer completely. Intermediate alpha values with white or black will make the underlying map lighter or darker and may increase contrast for the point markers.
        Returns:
        The background color for the map overlay.

      • setMapPointsTimeout

        public void setMapPointsTimeout(int timeout)
        Set the timeout interval for MapPoints. When the timeout expires, MapPoints is set to null to reduce long-term memory use. Otherwise, the data is kept in memory until the user session ends. Any redisplay, pan, zoom or select of the map restarts the timeout interval.
        Parameters:
        timeout - The timeout interval for the map points data in msec.

      • getMapPointsTimeout

        public int getMapPointsTimeout()
        The timeout interval for MapPoints. When the timeout expires, MapPoints is set to null to reduce long-term memory use. Otherwise, the data is kept in memory until the user session ends. Any redisplay, pan, zoom or select of the map restarts the timeout interval.
        Returns:
        The timeout interval for the map points data in msec.

      • getBoundingBoxWidth

        public long getBoundingBoxWidth()
        The width of the bounding box in pixels with zoom = MAX_ZOOM. The value is set by computeBoundingBox(). The bounding box is the smallest rectangle that includes all map points.
        Returns:
        The width of the bounding box.

      • getBoundingBoxHeight

        public long getBoundingBoxHeight()
        The height of the bounding box in pixels with zoom = MAX_ZOOM. The value is set by computeBoundingBox(). The bounding box is the smallest rectangle that includes all map points.
        Returns:
        The height of the bounding box.

      • getMaxNumberOfBindVariables

        public static int getMaxNumberOfBindVariables()
        Returns:
        The maximum number of bind variables allowed in a query for the current database (-1 = no known limit).

      • setAutoScale

        public void setAutoScale(boolean autoScale)
        Set value controlling whether the map zoom level is set based on the size of the map in the browser or using the Zoom value. Used by the map template.
        Parameters:
        autoScale - True indicates to use the smallest zoom level so that all map points are visible based on the actual size of the map in the browser. False indicates to use the Zoom value, as computed by computeBoundingBox() based on InitialHeight and InitialWidth. Typically use 'true' for the first display of the map and 'false' thereafter.

      • getAutoScale

        public boolean getAutoScale()
        Parameter controlling whether the map zoom level is set based on the size of the map in the browser or using the Zoom value. Used by the map template.
        Returns:
        True indicates to use the smallest zoom level so that all map points are visible based on the actual size of the map in the browser. False indicates to use the Zoom value, as computed by computeBoundingBox() based on InitialHeight and InitialWidth. Typically use 'true' for the first display of the map and 'false' thereafter.

      • renderMapTemplate

        public abstract java.lang.String renderMapTemplate(java.lang.String mapOption)
        Renders the HTML template for the map control. That is, it substitutes parameters into the template. The result is embedded in an iframe in the web page. The HTML template references and will include the JavaScript generated by renderJavaScriptTemplate().

        Parameters:
        mapOption - option value parameter passed to the template
        Returns:
        the rendered HTML code

      • getMap

        public static HeatMapGeneratorBase getMap(java.lang.String mapName)
        Get the named HeatMapGenerator associated with this user session. The mapName is used to distinguish between multiple maps, whether on a single screen or multiple screens. mapName is set in the HeatMapGenerator() constructor
        Parameters:
        mapName - The map name.
        Returns:
        The HeatMapGenerator instance.

      • computeBoundingBox

        public void computeBoundingBox()
        Computes a bounding box for the map, which is the smallest rectangle that includes all map points and, if set, the "area of interest". The bounding box is typically used to set the initial center point (CenterLat, CenterLng) and Zoom of the map so that all the map points are visible.

        This method uses the values for MapPoints and AreaOfInterest to set CenterLat, CenterLng, BoundingBoxWidth and BoundingBoxHeight.

        If InitialHeight and InitialWidth are non-zero, those values and Margin are used to set Zoom so that all points are visible in the map window. Margin is the number of pixels of extra space to allow at the four edges of the map.

        Note that you must set InitialHeight when using the default BingMap.gst template, which uses that value as the fixed map height. The map width is determined dynamically based on screen width and layout. The template code uses BoundingBoxXRange and BoundingBoxYRange to set Zoom correctly in the browser.

        The bounding box will span the international date line if that gives a smaller longitude range, which affects only BoundingBoxXRange and BoundingBoxYRange.

      • generateMapTile

        public void generateMapTile(java.awt.Graphics2D g2d,
                            gw.api.heatmap.XYTileId XYTileId)
        Generate a 256x256 pixel map overlay tile. The base method generates the heat map image.

        Override this method to modify the appearance of the overlay, for example to add lines, shading or text. To add elements behind the heat map, draw in g2d before calling super.generateHeatMap(). To add elements on top of the heat map, call super.generateHeatMap() first.

        Use these formulas to convert from latitude/longitude to g2d coordinates: 

           int zoomScale = MAX_ZOOM - XYTileId.zoom;
   int x = ((int)lngToX(lng) >> zoomScale) - (XYTileId.x << 8);
   int y = ((int)latToY(lat) >> zoomScale) - (XYTileId.y << 8);
        Parameters:
        g2d - the graphics context for the tile, which has a 256x256 pixel drawing area
        XYTileId - the tile identification

      • getMapFrameHTML

        public java.lang.String getMapFrameHTML()
        The HTML that appears inside the map frame. This is generated from the map template.
        Returns:
        The map frame HTML passed into HeatMapGenerator

      • getColorForValues

        public java.awt.Color getColorForValues(int[] values)
        Maps per-pixel point counts to colors for the map overlay. The default implementation calls DataSets[*].ColorMap.getColorForValue() for each data set in order. The first non-null value returned is the pixel color.

        Most commonly you'll change the ColorMap in each dataSet to control the mapping. The default method has the pixel color returned from the first data set hide the pixel color from subsequent datasets. For simple color changes, change ColorMap in each dataset. Override this routine if the values[] -> color relationship is more complex.

        Note that the overlay image generation routines don't use this when the values are all 0; use setOverlayBackgroundColor() instead to set the overlay background color.

        Parameters:
        values - The weighted value of points associated with a pixel, by DataSet. The value from getDataSet(0) is in counts[0], and so forth. A value of -1 indicates there is no data for the pixel, for which the method should return null.
        Returns:
        The color corresponding to the values, which may be null, indicating not to draw anything

      • lngToX

        public static long lngToX(double longitude)
        Convert the longitude to a map coordinate.
        Parameters:
        longitude - the longitude -180..180
        Returns:
        a map X coordinate in the range 0..2**(MAX_ZOOM + 7)-1

      • latToY

        public static long latToY(double latitude)
        Convert the latitude to a map coordinate. Note that latitude increases going North while the Y coordinate increases going South.
        Parameters:
        latitude - the latitude -90..90
        Returns:
        a map Y coordinate in the range 0..2**(MAX_ZOOM + 7)-1

      • xToLng

        public static double xToLng(long x)
        Convert an X map coordinate to longitude.
        Parameters:
        x - a map X coordinate in the range 0..2**(MAX_ZOOM + 7)-1
        Returns:
        the longitude -180..180

      • yToLat

        public static double yToLat(long y)
        Convert a Y map coordinate to latitude. Note that latitude increases going North while the Y coordinate increases going South.
        Parameters:
        y - a map Y coordinate in the range 0..2**(MAX_ZOOM + 7)-1
        Returns:
        the latitude -90..90

      • getSelectionMessage

        public java.lang.String getSelectionMessage()
        The message shown when the user selects an area on the map, for immediate display. Override this method to return a non-empty message. (SelectionMessageID must also be set to identify where to show the message.) For example, the message could give the total number of map points selected and the total dollar value associated with them.
        Returns:
        The message string.

      • getToolTip

        public java.lang.String getToolTip(LatLong clickPoint)
        Override this method to enable tooltips on the map. This method will be invoked each time the user clicks on the map. Use wrapToolTip() to generate the return value of this function. Returning an empty string means no tooltip should be displayed.
        Parameters:
        clickPoint - the position of the mouse click
        Returns:
        the tooltip string

      • wrapToolTip

        public java.lang.String wrapToolTip(java.lang.String tooltip,
                                    LatLong point)
        Wraps an HTML tooltip. Use this in getToolTip() to generate the return value. Tooltip contains the HTML for the tooltip, for example: line1
        line2. If point is non-null, use that lat/long instead of the mouse click point to position the tooltip.
        Parameters:
        tooltip - the HTML string for the tooltip.
        point - where to position the tooltip (null means use the exact mouse click point.
        Returns:
        the wrapped value to return in getToolTip

      • handleRequest

        public void handleRequest(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest servletRequest,
                          javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponse servletResponse)
                   throws java.io.IOException
        Process an HTTP request for the map overlay.

        Override this method (and modify the Javascipt in the map template) to add additional AJAX-style HTTP interactions between the browser and server for the heatmap. An example of an existing interaction: when the user pans the map, the browser sends the new center latitude and longitude to the server immediately and the values are saved into HeatMapGenerator. The first line of the overriding method should be a call to super.handleRequest().

        CAUTION: This is not yet a permanent committed interface to this functionality. It may be changed in future releases. If it does change, you will need to modify your code to achieve the same functionality. To avoid conflict with Guidewire-defined HTTP parameters, we recommend you prefix any new HTML parameter names with a capital letter X.

        The following parameters are used at this time:

        • mapName map.html tile legend centerLat centerLng point1Lat point1Lng point2Lat point2Lng ttLat ttLng zoomLevel
        Parameters:
        servletRequest - the HTTP request
        servletResponse - the response
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - possible exception from writing the output stream
